{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3544674,"name":"","username":"potatoez0319","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T04:36:34.154Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone!

I’m pretty new to robotics and I was able to get my hands on a REV through bore encoder (Through Bore Encoder - REV Robotics). I would like to get encoder counts using this bore encoder using my arduino mega. Is this possible to do and if it is, is there a library I could use in arduino to obtain encoder counts? Thanks so much!!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T04:36:34.154Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":37,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":208.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1271/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Through Bore Encoder - REV Robotics","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73902,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3544676,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T04:55:36.752Z","cooked":"

It’s a quadrature encoder and there are several libraries that will with with those. See https://docs.arduino.cc/libraries/quadratureencoder/

Note that that rev encoder’s resolution is pretty high (8192 transition per revolution), which means that the mega may have trouble keeping up.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T04:55:36.752Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":52.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.arduino.cc/libraries/quadratureencoder/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544840,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T14:33:55.634Z","cooked":"

I believe you could also use the pulseIn() function to read the encoder pwm pulses in absolute mode.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T14:34:05.686Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":38.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://reference.arduino.cc/reference/en/language/functions/advanced-io/pulsein/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"pulseIn() - Arduino Reference","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544885,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T15:53:51.251Z","cooked":"

How to use this encoder will depend on the mode of operation you choose, absolute or incremental.

Absolute generares a pulse, you would measure it’s widthe with pulseIn().

Incremental would use two channels and a quadrature library.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T15:53:51.251Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":20.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"billbo911","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842"},"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/4","custom_user_title":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3545087,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T21:18:37.722Z","cooked":"

The above solutions work great for getting off the ground, and getting systems working. Would recommend those approaches to start out, and you’ll probably never see a problem.

If you do see problems, this should help: The main issue with using pulseIn() for the absolute position is that it’s a “blocking” read, so it completely halts all other code execution: This is “short” in human time, but the pulse by definition of the waveform, is 5%-10% of the Arduino’s cpu time. Worse, you have to wait for that first “rising” edge, then wait for it to go back down; This means you might be spinning in a wait cycle until you see the rising edge, then wait for the falling edge, consuming upwards of 100% of the code cycle.
For dedicated tasks, this is fine; You’re basically going to be running “do nothing” loops anyway, and the worst case is doing 1 “normal loop” per signal pulse. But if you’re doing latency-sensitive tasks (like capturing multiple such signals, or trying to capture other sensor inputs), this will add up and you’ll start seeing random weird problems.
One such problem you might see is that if this sensor gets disconnected, pulseIn() will simply never complete! It waits for the signal which never shows up.

The easiest fix for that is probably just rely on the quadrature encoder as your primary data source; This runs on interrupts, which is much more efficient. Eg, the encoder “interrupts” your normal code and just says “Hey i rotated a bit” and your code continues. Then, just read the pulseIn() at program start and tell the relative encoder what initial position it should have.

Another option is to find a library like https://github.com/dmadison/ServoInput that allows you to read this type of signal waveform directly using interrupts. I haven’t used this specific one, but seems like the exact solution for ease of use and dodging problems.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-03T05:06:24.640Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":44,"readers_count":43,"score":8.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63359,"username":"predobrega","name":"Pedro Braga","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73902,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3546337,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-03T19:34:20.072Z","cooked":"

It’s going to depend on your velocities (and “bounciness”/backlash) of your system. If you’re rotating relatively slowly, you should be fine, but worth keeping an eye on.

Basically, ever tiny bit of a rotation that encoder is going to cause an interrupt to the system that says “Hey update my position kthx” which takes a small, but nonzero amount of time. If you’re rotating the process is

  • do work
  • “hey i moved”
  • work
  • work
  • “hey i moved”

which is what you expect and want to happen.
However at high velocities (in terms of “encoder ticks per second”) , it turns turns to

  • work
  • “hey i moved”
  • “hey i moved”
  • “hey i moved”
  • “hey i moved”
  • work
  • “hey i moved”

At this stage the encoder position will get lost, because it’s still trying to handle the last update, and it’s now missing new ones. This will show up as the encoder basically falling short and failing to properly register the position. You can resolve this by either a faster IC can take more updates per second, or you can use a lower resolution encoder which generates fewer updates per second.

If you’re worried, a good way to handle this is to just benchmark it: Have your system do a a bunch of slow stuff (make it do trig, that’ll show it), and then print how long it took. Don’t use delay() for this. Then just start rotating your encoder shaft, and watch what happens to the time between print statements, and the encoder position. You’ll get a good sense of how this update process and velocities impacts your code, and how much extra work it’s making the CPU do. If you start seeing the position not update as fast as you’re spinning the shaft, and your print statements basically vanish, then you’ve far surpassed what the system is capable of.

Fortunately though, you can always use the absolute encoder part to resync the position from time to time, and the absolute position one will not have such drift; That’s being calculated by the through bore encoder, which will only lose steps at much higher RPMs than you’ll likely be using it for.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-03T19:34:20.072Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":36,"readers_count":35,"score":12.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":73902,"username":"potatoez0319","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/77aa72/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/10","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3546536,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-03T21:08:22.048Z","cooked":"

Depending on your needs, the Teensy 4.1 board. Also, a lot of ESP32-S3 boards.

The mega runs at 16 mhz. The Teensy is ~600mhz, iirc, and the ESPs are commonly 240 mhz. You need the speed to avoid spending all your time servicing interrupts from the encoder.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T00:19:18.226Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":3.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73902,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3546730,"name":"","username":"potatoez0319","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T00:22:06.225Z","cooked":"

Thanks for your reply! For the teensy, would it have enough pins to support 4 motors and 2 rev bore encoders as well as their motor controllers?

On another note, do the rev bore encoders need motor controllers? Sorry if these questions are silly, I am still a bit ambivalent on wiring the entire robot.

potatoez0319:

For the teensy, would it have enough pins to support 4 motors and 2 rev bore encoders as well as their motor controllers?

Probably, yeah. Here’s a chart with the pin capabilities of the 4.1.

card11a_rev3_web632×685 231 KB

Unless you wanna go down a particularly deep rabbit hole of CAN wizardry, you should probably stick to pwm controls here, even if they are a little limiting.

potatoez0319:

On another note, do the rev bore encoders need motor controllers?

No. Here are the wiring diagrams rev provides. You can just swap out the rio for your microcontroller here: Application Examples | REV Crossover Products

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T02:01:34.729Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":18.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493826,"topic_slug":"using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/rev-crossover-products/sensors/tbe/application-examples#ni-roborio","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Application Examples | REV Crossover Products","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/using-rev-bore-encoder-with-arduino/493826/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3546855,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T02:11:05.611Z","cooked":"

Teensies have more than enough IO for that. If you run into problems with encoders and velocities, try some of these tips. Paul over at PJRC optimizes libraries that interact with the Teensy for ridiculous performance. This also has some ballpark metrics for what the teensy can actually handle during normal operation.
https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/td_libs_Encoder.html

You can run the motors using PWM with no problem, teensy has lots of PWM capable outputs. Similarly, you can run the Through Bore with no motor controller. We used a Teensy in basically this configuration for our non-FRC marketing bot.

Do be wary of your power supplies though. Motors generate a lot of voltage spikes, and the teensy is not battle-hardened against this like many electronics used in FRC. There’s two good ways to mitigate this:

  • Avoid bundling your PWM or encoder wires parallel to your motor lines for long distances. Give them a good inch or two of space, and run them seperately. If you bundle them together, and for a long run, the motor can induce voltage spikes that fry the IO line or the whole teensy.
  • Have a good, 5V regulator going into the teensy. Ideally using a USB battery pack and powering it that way, since it’s complete isolated from the motors. Powering teensies and using USB at the same time requires some extra attention which you wouldn’t do on most arduino boards. There’s documentation for this. https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/external_power.html
